video.title: TEDTalks: Ancient Clues
video.synopsis: Investigators of the Earth's ancient past uncover astonishing new revelations and bold predictions for mankind's future.

episodes.synopsis: A paleontologist takes descendants of the dinosaur -- chickens -- and genetically engineers them to make a "Chickenosaurus."
episodes.title: Jack Horner: Building a Dinosaur from a Chicken

episodes.synopsis: A geneticist shows the DNA proof that early humans mated with Neanderthals after humankind moved out of Africa.
episodes.title: Svante Pääbo: DNA Clues to Our Inner Neanderthal

episodes.synopsis: Rajesh Rao is fascinated by "the mother of all crossword puzzles": How to decipher the 4,000-year-old Indus script.
episodes.title: Rajesh Rao: A Rosetta Stone for the Indus Script

episodes.synopsis: With stunning illustrations, David Christian narrates a complete history of the universe, from the Big Bang to the Internet.
episodes.title: David Christian: Big History

episodes.synopsis: A paleontologist talks about his surprising encounters with prehistory -- and a new way to help students join the adventure.
episodes.title: Paul Sereno Digs Up Dinosaurs

episodes.synopsis: A paleoanthropologist looks for the roots of humanity in Ethiopia's badlands. How does Africa hold the clues to our humanity?
episodes.title: Zeresenay Alemseged Looks for Humanity's Roots

episodes.synopsis: Elaine Morgan talks about the idea that humans evolved from primate ancestors who dwelt in watery habitats.
episodes.title: Elaine Morgan Says We Evolved from Aquatic Apes

episodes.synopsis: The author of the Medea hypothesis argues that most of Earth's mass extinctions were caused not by asteroid strikes but by bacteria.
episodes.title: Peter Ward on Earth's Mass Extinctions

episodes.synopsis: Rob Dunbar hunts for data on our climate from 12,000 years ago, finding clues inside ancient seabeds and inside ice sheets.
episodes.title: Rob Dunbar: Discovering Ancient Climates in Oceans and Ice

episodes.synopsis: A hardy team in Antarctica is drilling into 10,000-year-old ice to extract vital data on our changing climate.
episodes.title: Lee Hotz: Inside an Antarctic Time Machine

episodes.synopsis: Adam Savage talks about his fascination with the dodo bird, and how it led him on a strange and surprising double quest.
episodes.title: Adam Savage's Obsessions

episodes.synopsis: A biologist shares his theory about why humans evolved a complex system of language, as it offered early tribes access to a new tool: cooperation.
episodes.title: Mark Pagel: How Language Transformed Humanity

episodes.synopsis: Hendrik Poinar talks about the quest to engineer a creature much like the woolly mammoth. The first step, to sequence the genome, is nearly complete.
episodes.title: Hendrik Poinar: Bring Back the Woolly Mammoth!

episodes.synopsis: Neil MacGregor, director of the British Museum, traces 2,600 years of history through the Cyrus Cylinder, a powerful symbol of multiculturalism.
episodes.title: Neil MacGregor: 2,600 Years of History in One Object

episodes.synopsis: Writer Christopher McDougall explores the human desire to run, discussing how the activity helped early humans survive and what spurs us to run today.
episodes.title: Christopher McDougall: Are We Born to Run?

episodes.synopsis: Mona Lisa is one of the best-known faces, but would you recognize the man who painted her? Siegfried Woldhek seeks out the face of Leonardo da Vinci.
episodes.title: Siegfried Woldhek: The Search for the True Face of Leonardo

episodes.synopsis: Ancient books curator William Noel tells the story behind a 2,000-year-old manuscript that had been erased, cut up, written on and painted over.
episodes.title: William Noel: Revealing the Lost Codex of Archimedes

episodes.synopsis: From simple alphabets to secret symbolic languages, graphic designer Saki Mafundikwa celebrates the many forms of written communication across Africa.
episodes.title: Saki Mafundikwa: Ingenuity and Elegance in Ancient African Alphabets

episodes.synopsis: Primatologist Isabel Behncke Izquierdo shows how bonobo apes learn from play, which is key to that society's problem-solving and avoiding conflict.
episodes.title: Isabel Behncke: Evolution's Gift of Play, from Bonobo Apes to Humans
